content:
Needs more and longer tests for reverse mode. I just had this clash and figured out the pattern is "maximum size of a group when grouping the words by their length" (code below) which works for all the visible tests, but then failed 50% of the validators. If you only have 3 different outputs (1, 2, 3) there are always going to be countless different ways to get to the same numbers with only 4 tests.

print(max(Counter(len(word) for word in input().split()).values()))

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great puzzle, perfect for reverse mode, I like the difficulty. Well done.

I really like the concept. However, I feel that there should be a test cases with just one word in it, and that word is an obvious palindrome. If that is implemented, I think it would make a great fit and I would be happy to approve it.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like the idea, it doesn't seem to hard to understand what to do without reading the name

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good one
Changed test case to invalidate this idea, becauseit was indeed correct with test cases but not what was expected
Fixing this specific pattern doesn't address the larger issue, you really need more test cases to make it less likely for people to find wrong patterns.

I do not agree with you on this point. The aim of reverse is to be like an enigma. You have pretty obvious clues in the test cases, like the second one with "kayak" which is an obvious palindrome. If you try random code without reading all test cases, you know that you take a risk that maybe your logic is flawed

I mean you can rather easily find patterns that work because the output space is so ridiculously tiny. Over 1% ((1/3)^4) of attempts will pass the tests even if you mindlessly try COMPLETELY random patterns that produce output from 1 to 3. If you use just a little bit of brainpower that chance goes up by a lot. Three different distinct outputs is simply not enough for a reverse mode.

To demonstrate the point here's three more patterns that pass all the visible tests:
* count the words that end in one of the letters "mlkt"
* count the occurrences of patterns XYX and XX (where X and Y can be any character, case-insensitive)
* find the 1-based index of the first word that contains one of the letters "aei"

This clash definitely needs extra tests/validators.

Especially since the last one is the only one where upper/lower case matters, so it's a pain in Reverse mode when you try to submit once you see it passing the tests and press it too early. At least one more test/validator pair would help a lot.
